intro: Podanthus mitiqui, commonly known as the Andean bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes in South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or violet flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in cool, temperate climates. Podanthus mitiqui has lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. Its ornamental value makes it a sought-after plant for alpine gardens and botanical collections.
